content: The Act titled "TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005" allows for the advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 authorizes the advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006, extending activities through December 31, 2005. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 allows payments to be made through the first quarter of fiscal year 2006 at the same level as in fiscal year 2005. Amendments include changing deadlines and years for certain grants and funds under the Social Security Act. Extension of the National Random Sample Study of Child Welfare and Child Welfare Waiver Authority is extended through December 31, 2005, with necessary appropriations from the Treasury. Grants and payments can continue through the first quarter of fiscal year 2006 at the same level as in fiscal year 2005. SEC. 3. Reimbursement of states for TANF benefits provided to assist families affected by Hurricane Katrina from other states. Beginning with the enactment of this Act until August 31, 2006, a State can qualify as a needy State under section 403(b) of the Social Security Act if they have provided short-term, nonrecurring cash benefits to families displaced by Hurricane Katrina from another State declared a disaster area. The State can qualify as a needy State under the Social Security Act by providing short-term cash benefits to families displaced by Hurricane Katrina from another State declared a disaster area. The total amount paid to a State for this purpose should not exceed the cash benefits provided to the families, and no state match is required for the payment. SEC. 4. AVAILABILITY OF ADDITIONAL TANF FUNDS FOR HURRICANE-DAMAGED STATES. Beginning with the enactment of this Act until the end of fiscal year 2006, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama are eligible for loans under the Social Security Act. The total loan amount for these states cannot exceed 20% of the State family assistance grant for fiscal year 2006. Additionally, these states will not face penalties for failing to repay the loans before October 1. The Act allows states to repay loans or make interest payments on loans received under the Social Security Act before October 1, 2007. SEC. 5 allows states or tribes to use unspent TANF funds to support needy families affected by Hurricane Katrina without time limitations. SEC. 6 states that work requirements and time limits under the TANF program are not triggered by families receiving temporary benefits due to the hurricane. SEC. 7 waives TANF penalties in hurricane-damaged states. SEC. 7 waives TANF penalties in hurricane-damaged states of Louisiana, Mississippi, or Alabama for non-compliance with certain provisions due to Hurricane Katrina or state's efforts to assist victims.
